thread.title_full: Kiwi Illafonte’s ‘Seeds’ Taps Nina Simone For an Uplifting Protest Message

author: Emma Silvers
title: Kiwi Illafonte’s ‘Seeds’ Taps Nina Simone For an Uplifting Protest Message
text:
Ed. note: As long as humans have been making music, it’s been used as a form of protest. As part of KQED Arts’ 100 Days project, documenting artists’ responses to our new administration in its earliest days, I’ve asked Bay Area musicians to get in touch with songs they’ve written or recorded that serve as reactions to our current political climate. Over the next couple months, I’ll be highlight the most compelling entries I receive, along with a few words from the artist about their inspirations and intentions. 
Kiwi Illafonte, “Seeds” 
“I wrote the lyrics to ‘Seeds’ not long after Trump’s election was confirmed. In addition to my own thoughts about it, the song was also informed and inspired by the insights of my friends and community folks, many of whom are local activists and organizers,” Kiwi Illafonte told me by email when I asked about this new track. Its title plays on the expression — often associated with the Zapatista movement — “They tried to bury us; they didn’t know we were seeds.”
A longtime Oakland resident originally from LA, Illafonte’s probably best known as one-third of the hip-hop trio Native Guns project. But he’s also a volunteer educator with ROOTS (Restoring Our Original True Selves), a community education program that works with the Asian and Pacific Islander population at San Quentin State Prison. He’s also worked with MIGRANTE Northern California , an organization that advocates for Filipino migrant workers, as well as PAWIS (People’s Association of Workers and Immigrants), a local group advocating for Filipino domestic workers, caregivers, and other migrant workers in the East Bay.
“The feeling that stuck out to me the most was disappointment and anger — at the lack of common sense and humanity — of those who supported Trump,” he said, “as well as uncertainty about what a Trump presidency would mean to those of us in this country who exist on the margins. I felt writing a song was the most healthy means I had to process all those emotions.”
The track features three spoken-word samples, interludes from George Carlin, Jay Smooth, and Nina Simone. The latter, he says, in which Simone discusses artists’ responsibilities in society, has been one of his favorite quotes for a while.
“I believe it’s an artist’s role to reflect society; to provoke, educate, comfort, offer relief,” he says. “But I also feel that, if an artist decides that they are going to speak on a political issue, that they seek out those on the front lines of that issue, i.e organizers and activists.
“There are so many well-intentioned artists who try to speak up on issues but their analysis ends up sounding weak and/or incomplete. I am blessed to be surrounded by — and accountable to — many Bay Area activists that have been organizing for years around issues like gentrification, police violence, the school-to-prison pipeline, and violence against women. They’ve definitely informed how I speak and write about the problems that impact our communities.”

Oh, and yeah: I post newish local songs I like on Fridays now. Got something I should hear? esilvers@kqed.org .
